title: Pro Log: Shari Bossuyt tests positive for Letrozole, Covid protocols return for the Tour de France, Tiberi and Gee contracts and new Greg LeMond documentary
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Shari Bossuyt tests positive for Letrozole, Covid protocols return for the Tour de France, Tiberi and Gee contracts and new Greg LeMond documentary

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. It’s been a while after a hiatus for the Giro d’Italia rest day recaps, but normal service has resumed. The Critérium du Dauphiné is currently ongoing and I think a lot of us enjoyed seeing Julian Alaphilippe (Soudal-QuickStep) win the second stage into La Chaise-Dieu.

1. Shari Bossuyt tests positive for Letrozole

Shari Bossuyt returned a positive test for Letrozole during the Tour de Normandie Féminin in March and has been made provisionally ‘non-active’ by her Canyon-SRAM team. In a press conference on Monday, Bossuyt said she would prove she is ‘not a cheater’ and that this is an issue of contamination.

Letrozole can be used to treat breast cancer and is a banned drug on the World Anti-Doping Agency Prohibited List due to its potential use with anabolic steroids to avoid adverse effects and/or boost testosterone production. Belgian cyclocross rider Toon Aerts also tested positive for Letrozole in an out-of-competition sample in 2022 and claims it was due to contamination. He faces a two-year suspension.

pic.twitter.com/iWTlodms17

— Aerts Toon (@ToAerts) June 4, 2023

Aerts tweeted his support for Bossuyt, saying, ‘We are one year on, I’m still deep in misery, and unfortunately there is another case. I can imagine so well what Shari is going through now. This shouldn’t happen. Another athlete, who is also human, who will go through a deep valley with her whole family.’

Canyon-SRAM stated they have a ‘zero tolerance’ approach to doping and will await the decision of the French Anti-Doping Agency (AFLD) before taking further action.

2. Face masks return to the Tour de France

Following the wave of Covid-19 infections at the Giro d’Italia, which forced riders including then-race leader Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep) to abandon the race, organiser ASO plans to put a new protocol in place for the Tour de France to limit the risk of infections.

The measures have apparently been seen by Reuters and include face masks required at the sign-on and in the team paddock, no dining out, no selfies or autographs for fans, and social distancing.

3. Bahrain Victorious sign Antonio Tiberi

Welcome, Antonio Tiberi!

Team Bahrain Victorious has signed former junior World Champion @AntonioTiberi4 until the end of the 2025 season.#RideAsOne

https://t.co/T15rTWWaLm pic.twitter.com/Z4Eh8t8xIa

— Team Bahrain Victorious (@BHRVictorious) June 1, 2023

Antonio Tiberi, who was fined €4,000 after killing the San Marino Minister of Tourism’s cat with an air rifle, has been signed by Bahrain Victorious. The 21-year-old was initially suspended by former team Trek-Segafredo in March, but actions during his suspension apparently resulted in the termination of his contract.

Bahrain Victorious announced their new signing by saying his opportunities this season have been ‘limited’, but that Tiberi can thrive in their environment.

4. Derek Gee extends with Israel-Premier Tech

In other contract news, Derek Gee has signed a six-year extension with Israel-Premier Tech, which would see him riding for the team through the 2028 season. The news comes after Gee lit up the Giro d’Italia through breakaways and second-places galore in both stages and classifications. The 25-year-old Canadian ultimately won the overall combativity award.

Gee said, ‘So many second places made me extremely hungry to get that first win and hopefully one day get a stage win in a Grand Tour. I’d like to continue to develop without necessarily picking something to specialise in, and just see which direction racing takes me in as a rider.’

I’m looking forward to seeing it.

5. The Last Rider: A new Greg LeMond documentary

Cycling documentaries are booming. From Movistar’s Least Expected Day to the upcoming Tour de France: Unchained.

Now, it’s Greg LeMond’s turn. The only American rider to win the Tour de France, not only is he one of the most successful riders of all time, but his comeback from being shot in the chest and winning the 1989 Tour de France is a story for the ages. The documentary The Last Rider will be in select cinemas from June 23rd.

The Tour de France: Unchained docuseries drops on Netflix this Thursday, no spoilers but look out for the Danish guy.

Happy watching.

The post Pro Log: Shari Bossuyt tests positive for Letrozole, Covid protocols return for the Tour de France, Tiberi and Gee contracts and new Greg LeMond documentary appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Robyn Davidson | Editorial Assistant
